title: OnOptions
description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

items.title: Gavin Newsom signs law to regulate AI, protect kids and teens from chatbots
items.description: Newsom, who has four children under 18, said California has a responsibility to protect kids and teens who turn to AI chatbots.

items.title: Top analyst warns that ‘larger than expected correction is likely’ if Trump and China don’t kiss and make up
items.description: If the truce in the trade war doesn’t resume by early November, Morgan Stanley’s Mike Wilson writes, brace for a 10% to 15% haircut.

items.title: Why Your Company’s Reputation Matters More Than Ever to Jobseekers
items.description: The job market may be tough, but applicants are still being selective.

items.title: Metro Mattress is closing stores and winding down operations: See the list of locations that will shutter

items.title: There will be 500,000 seasonal hires this holiday season. Half of them will work for Amazon
items.description: Amazon will once again beef up its workforce in the fourth quarter to handle the expected shopping surge that comes with the holidays. This year, thou...

items.title: Ex-Apple CEO John Sculley Says This Company Is Apple’s First ‘Real Competitor’ in Years
items.description: Sculley led Apple from 1983 to 1993. He has some thoughts about how the company is doing today.

items.title: OpenAI partners with Broadcom to make an ideal AI chip (and get distance from Nvidia)
items.description: OpenAI and Broadcom have formed a multibillion-dollar partnership to develop OpenAI-designed chips. Under the deal, OpenAI will design the chips to it...

items.title: Strava CEO says the $2 billion unicorn plans to go public ‘at some point’ as marathon-obsessed Gen Z swaps dating apps for run clubs
items.description: CEO Michael Martin said a public listing would provide easy capital for future acquisitions.

items.title: The rare Taylor Swift backlash, explained: Why some fans feel jilted by the star’s tradwife, almost MAGA-coded turn
items.description: Earlier this month, Swift told the BBC it was “shockingly offensive” to ask whether she was dropping her last album before getting married and having ...

items.title: Lawsuit: New York is accusing Meta and Alphabet of spurring a youth mental health crisis
items.description: The Big Apple is taking on the companies behind Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok , and YouTube, accusing them of “public nuisance” and spurring a...

items.title: How Tighter RTO Rules May Cost Employers High Performer Pet Owners
items.description: A new report shows employees with pets will bolt jobs that reduce their flexibility to work in the company of their animals.

items.title: Taylor Swift’s Fans Are Angry About Her Use of AI. It’s a Warning to All Leaders
items.description: After Taylor Swift launched a video apparently made with AI, #SwiftiesAgainstAI is trending. It’s a reminder to be careful of AI backlash.

items.title: Do you still need to pay taxes during a government shutdown?

items.title: CEO says she’d welcome an AI-bot board member: ‘If you don’t have an AI agent in every meeting, you’re missing out’
items.description: Hanneke Faber speaks about the value of AI in decision making at Fortune’s Most Powerful Women conference.

items.title: White House Decimates Entire Staff Behind Small Business-Friendly Capital Program
items.description: While CDFIs may not be the first stop for capital for most entrepreneurs, stripping it of its team is a blow to access to capital.
